pros: No pros working at this organisation.
cons:
This organisation is like a black mark on my resume. Poor learning experience, no work streamline, and the co-founders also lack vision. Despite surviving from many years, they still don't have a proper financial model and fail to generate revenue, rather they depend on some external organisation for funding without a solid product or service. When it comes to culture, they don't give a damn about your growth and personal well-being. Never seen anyone getting promotions or appraisals in this organisation. They stop paying you all of a sudden and fire you without prior notice giving crappy reasons like not reaching expectations, even if you are associated with them for a long time. They really need to be called out and that's one of the main reasons why LetsEndorse isn't successful, they don't value people.
This organisation is a perfect example of "how not to run a company".

pros: You learn a lot plus work environment is very homely.

On a mission to westernize the developing world by perpetuating industrial agriculture (and indirectly, harmful diet) practices
Not recommended for anyone looking to make a positive impact on the environment through their career

review_title: Interesting & challenging work - potential for real impact
pros:
- Interesting work, well connected, smart people. 
- Colleagues push you to continue working hard & striving great work  
- Visible media & press coverage in well respected news papers
- theory & approach open to analysis and critique 
- Arguably the company has been on the forefront of certain systemic market interventions
- Work from home options available (manager dependent) 
- Great health and retirement benefits 
- Limited, but growing opportunities for continued academic study (courses, trainings, certifications, etc.) 
- Relatively strong global presence in agricultural business development & increasingrecognition for work in entrepreneurship
- Diversity of donors keeps work interesting and sustainable
cons:
The overall working environment/experience & opportunities for growth & learning heavily linked to which office you work in, who your immediate supervisor is, and who represents your interests at the senior level. 

- Ineffective team leadership 
- Poor communication
- Awkward interpersonal skills and management styles
- Unclear and inconsistent messaging to staff (especially on sensitive issues related to funding, sudden departures & indirect) 
-Lack of clear career channels within dept & teams
-'churn em and burn em' mentality at the lower levels 
- Employee review period unclear how performance links to raise and/or promotion

pros: TechnoServe has a creative vision- While many non profit organization are bloated and have a pity orientation to the beneficiaries that in many cases disempowers the beneficiaries, convincing them that they must depend on external assistance to change their situations, rather than being agents of change themselves.  As a result, TechnoServe is not a traditional assistance/donation oriented organization, by assisting businesses they allow beneficiaries to play active role in reducing rural poverty.  Some TechnoServe employees are very talented, bright and passionate about work and provide effective assistance to the businesses.  TechnoServe offers opportunity to invent and implement innovative economic assistance programs particularly in partnership with private sector. The volunteer consultant program is top notch in providing high class business assistance to rural businesses in the developing world.
cons: The organization would do well to apply some its business acumen to its own operations.  The organization is not implementing best practice in many areas such as: information management, training/evaluation of staff, client satisfaction surveys.  The HQ staff often give too much reins and doesn't have adequate supervision of the day to day operations in the country offices, resulting in poor brand management-- inconsistent levels of service and unfortunate situations involving big egos, racism, sexism, and slacking off in some of the country offices.  There are few opportunities for career advancement in the organization, and there is a lot of reinventing of the wheel that takes place.

pros: Comfortable work setting for employees
cons: Significantly low benefit and professional development

pros:
- Organization's vision is relevant and important: improving the lives of farmers' is central to any country's development
- Opportunity to travel - visits to the field are always interesting
- People are fun (partly because not many take the work seriously - see con below)
- Field staff are extremely dedicated
cons:
- In many ways, the organization epitomizes all that is wrong with the development sector: bidding for projects despite having no real comparative advantage in the area; significant portion of project budget goes to pay senior leadership salaries instead of operations; focus is to satisfy the donor rather create any impact.
- Country leadership completely disconnected from operations. Little clarity among staff on what leadership actually does.
- ''Volunteer" consultants - who earn more than regular staff -  bring a fresh perspective but too many see TechnoServe as a stepping stone for a MBA 
- "Business solutions to poverty" sounds nice in theory but often results in jargon-filled, albeit pretty, presentations in which synergies are created, low-hanging fruit is captured and core competencies are leveraged - but not much actually happens.

review_title: Entrepreneurship is a value, but not always success
pros: TechnoServe is a workplace that values entrepreneurship. If you want to solve an internal problem or develop a new program or business opportunity (and if you're a motivated self-starter), management is willing to work with you and has created new job titles and teams to support successful initiatives and ambitious employees. If you share that kind of mindset, or have a background in management consulting, there's a strong potential for career growth with the company.
cons: Management tends to be too decentralized and laissez faire with internal darlings, making it hard to systemize processes or impose order on programs or platforms that have drifted from success or sustainability. Because oversight and organization varies across divisions and country offices, bad employees can linger for way too long through manipulating and stifling information. Having the right advocate means you have free reign to subvert or ignore best practices. Even when issues are brought before management, they tend to be slow to course correct for poor performance.

pros: Worked for many of the well-known international development orgs and companies in the DC ecosystem and TechnoServe easily has the most intelligent and deep-thinking people of them all out of the DC home office and among the several field offices that I worked out of.  They are very rigorous and genuine in their work, religious about logical frameworks, showing REAL results.  People are brilliant and there is a high chance you meet people smarter than you whom you can learn from.
cons:
Extremely weak internal systems (the intranet is a Google based platform), very slow professional development unless you are operating out of the VolCon sphere, poor communication.  No feedback loops for employees and most of the directors and managers don't know how to supervise people.  

Strange and not very transparent divide between the public and private sector portions of the company.  Very top heavy organization.

review_title: Reputable org with compelling programs; not always well organized or efficient
pros:
- Reputable organization with good track record; well regarded  within the sector
- Mission driven team; compelling narrative around "business solutions to poverty" resonates well with donors
- Competitive pay compared to industry standards, at least if hired through HQ
- Intrapreneurial attitude; there is space to start new things and shake things up
- Interesting programs at the intersection of aid, business, and entrepreneurship
cons:
- Choices with regards to work systems and operations decentralized down to country offices. This means that efficiency, work quality, and office culture can vary greatly from one place to the other. Do your research first
- Lack of communication and integration between country offices, even when working on similar programs
- As with many organizations of this type, large pay discrepancies between expat and local employees abroad
- As a result of industry incentives, the organization is generally more interested in fundraising than delivering impact. There is a push for more evidence-driven work from HQ, but this hasn't reached field offices yet

review_title: Worked on the profile of Assistant Project Manager with TechnoServe India
pros:
It's a brilliant organisation who are working for the development of the farming community. If you are passionate to contribute in the developmental sector then it's a right place to work and contribute. TechnoServe having a very good working environment and team culture. You will get better learning opportunity & challenging task to perform on different Agro Business Project. 

I worked with technoServe for more than 3 years but its wonderful journey and i really enjoyed my each working day. Value, I learned at TechnoServe going to be my guiding path in my future career.
cons: I didn't saw any loopholes in the TechnoServe as an organisation to work.

review_title: A great organization to work with for all stages in career
pros: Top leadership is highly encouraging, enterprising and supportive. Leaders are great mentors. Performance culture - I got a surprise increment, never expected it. Professional working environment. Great opportunities for cross functional/sectional learning. Peers are very supportive and there is environment of collegiality and mutual respect among all levels of staff. Great inter departmental bonding. Well equipped guest house for project staff allows you to leave behind petty worries and focus on work.
cons: Its not a place for people who believe in the traditional development sector i.e. take long time to show impact. The organization really works hard on market led interventions and you have to keep pace with it.

pros: Mission - TechnoServe helps entrepreneurial men and women in poor rural areas of the developing world to build businesses that create income, opportunity and economic growth for their families, their communities and their countries.  echnoServe founded by Connecticut businessman Ed Bullard. After volunteering at a hospital in Ghana, Bullard was inspired to start an organization helping hardworking rural people harness the power of private enterprise to lift themselves out of poverty.  Climbing out of poverty in the developing world takes more than hard work; it takes economic opportunities. Entrepreneurs create these opportunities by identifying and capitalizing on good business ideas. TechnoServe helps them turn their visions into reality.
cons: Tough to move up in organization without advanced degree from top 10 school.

pros: Technoserve is a one of the most fulfilling non-profit organizations I've worked with.  This NGO teaches a fisherman how to fish, instead of giving them fish.  You go out in the field, you will see the happy faces of the farmers  growing their crops or a woman attending to her own business courtesy of TNS.  While salary is not one of the best in town, even compared with other non-profits, they do have excellent benefits including a 9% pension employer contribution.  They are also support working remotely or from-home, I like that a lot.
cons: There seems to be a trend of management changes at Technoserve, plus the low salary rates, of course.

pros: You are given absolute flexibility to make decisions and influence the outcome of the projects that you work on at TechnoServe.
cons: TechnoServe needs to improve of marketing and communications. The organization does a ton of good-work in the developing world and provides unparalleled expertise. However, TechnoServe does not know how to sell itself well beyond its usual donors. The company needs to tell and spread its story.

review_title: TechnoServe is a great employer, made of caring people, and provides an intellectual challenge to all its employees
pros:
- The other employees, intelligent and caring, the best mix.
- The mission and values of the organization, which it upholds in every project. 
- Many opportunities to travel.
- Provides exciting intellectual challenges.
- From what I have seen, very quick career advancement.
cons:
- Life/work balance is that of a consulting job – long hours, very little free time.
- Compensation, instead, is very far from that of a consulting job – but that is arguably what an organization aimed at alleviating poverty should provide.

pros: Incredible mandate and experience, young and knowledgeable teams, global reach with local impact.
cons: Incredibly poor management and internal systems. Complete lack of strategy and with little attention to impact. It feels like everything is done to chase funding. Senior country management doesnt seem to see the value of working towards common goals across all the country programs. Thats fine on an individual basis but is really damaging for TNS as a whole.

review_title: Incompetent Seniors who have zero understanding about development sector ground realities
pros:
Salary
Good for Short term experience
cons:
Senior management does not get involved in operations though people are going in wrong direction. Only numbers are important.

Orgnisation does not care at all about employees.
Zero knowledge about ground realities.

Unrealistic promises made to donors for getting funds.

Organisation does not encourage long term employment.

Lots of politics at the time of annual reviews. After joining very slow growth. 

Teams are pathetic to work with. Rat race is common.

Worst accounts and admin team.

Senior Managers salaries are way to high than their experience and capabilities

review_title: Great Organisation but bosses are horrible...
pros:
Best Salary Structure in development sector
Great learning experience.
cons:
Not recommended for pure development oriented professionals.
Overly target driven.
Disconnect of senior level management from actual ground realities.
Too much politics in between senior management effecting lower level staff.
Many incompetent senior managers are involved in  strategic decisions.
Unrealistic targets being set and then the ground team is forced to complete them.

pros: Great people who are mission-driven and very focused - working here you feel like you are actually contributing to some sustainable change. Many staff come from the private sector, so it feels different than a traditional NGO.
cons: As a non-profit, there are limited resources and a lot of work - people at TechnoServe end up working really hard (for not as much pay as in the private sector). Also, there is a bit of a disconnect between the work on the ground and the HQ in DC - all the teams feel very separate and far apart.

review_title: Kind-hearted organization, but a questionable model
pros:
- There are lots of smart, talented people who work here.
- Many leaders seem to genuinely care about making TechnoServe a good place to work.
cons:
- Like any nonprofit, this place is stretched pretty thin. 
- TechnoServe is extending the reach of capitalism, a system that can lift millions out of poverty but is also clearly making the planet uninhabitable.
- Is it OK for TechnoServe to take money from institutions to help the poor when that charitable giving is probably meant to whitewash the institution's misdeeds?

pros:
I had an amazing experience with TechnoServe Kenya. The experience really solidified my interest and commitment to the international development sector.

--Great management, they were invested in people and making sure VolCons had a positive experience
--Great organizational culture and alumni network, TNS did a good job of always trying to keep in touch and the regular newsletters are a wonderful way to stay in touch (would suggest redoing the outings and potentially more frequent newsletters)
--Nice mix between field work and office work
cons:
--Logistics (e.g., housing) could've been better in-house
--Better job of in-country onboarding

pros:
1,. Peer learning is great as they hire people with good pedigree.
2. Great 'halting' station before you join MBA.
3. Good opportunities for training and development for development professionals.
cons:
1. Total disconnect between the implementation team and strategy building team
2. Not a place to be in if you are serious about making career in development sector. It appears more like a volunteering work for MBA aspirants than serious developments sector professionals.  
3. No uniform systems and processes in place.

review_title: Good for experiencing the development sector
pros:
1. Great place for peer learning
2. The TechnoServe brand has good value in the industry
3. Among the better paymasters among the implementing agencies in the development sector
4. Useful resources for employee development
cons:
1. Disconnect between operational teams in project locations and the Head Office
2. Inflexible work arrangements
3. No policy regarding compensatory offs or employee insurance & medical benefits

review_title: Fabulous on-ground experience if one is interested in international development
pros:
1. Meaningful responsibilities and significant autonomy as a Volunteer Consultant
2. Great feeder organization to top MBA programs
3. Amazing network in management consulting, banking, and international development
cons:
1. Limited guidance and formal mentorship
2. Lifestyle can be difficult, although this depends on the projects you take on and your level of responsibility.
3. Not a great paymaster (but you should be okay with this if you are interested in international development long-term)

review_title: Work with bright and committed colleagues
pros:
*Work with extremely bright, committed and hardworking colleagues
*Non-hierarchical - place where you can get to know and have your opinions heard by leadership
*Entrepreneurial culture
*Pays well for a non-profit
*Current CEO has done a lot to improve people management
cons:
*Not a 9-5 job - many people work nights and some weekends (the flip side of being committed to the mission) 
*Lack of strong knowledge management combined with tendency towards siloed functions leads to a lot of reinventing the wheel

pros:
i like the company due to its products and services. 
also it is where my dream of working were
i am capable of this job
cons:
challenges depend though no challenge that can not be solved and not job without challenge
 i am for challenges in order to be competent more since challenges make one extend thinking and discover something new

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: The people who work there, and the people TechnoServe helps are amazing. I loved the vision, mission, and values. Also, great benefts.
cons: The culture is to work long and hard hours, but most entry and midlevels positions don't receive high enough compensation. Of course, this is often the case in non-profts.

pros: Impressive application of technology for internal operations and in working with farmer groups.
cons:
Top-down decision-making with no regard for implementation.
Too much importance placed on standardisation and ease of measuring results at the expense of actual needs and schedules of client farmers.

pros: Great working environment, everyone was really friendly and welcoming even though I was just an intern. Lots of flexibility in terms of when I worked. My supervisors were always willing to help and wanted me to get the most out of my internship. I would definitely recommend TechnoServe to anyone interested in international development.
cons: No cons - overall had a good experience here

review_title: A view from the proyect based employees
pros: You get to help people and society in a sustainable way. People in the organization are great. It is a fulfilling job.
cons: Project based contract means you know it’s going to end…

pros:
-work is really interesting, and coworkers are clearly passionate about their projects and the organization's mission
-CEO genuinely cares about the interns and makes time to talk to them about their experience
-Interns are expected to do real, high-impact work, and get a real firsthand look at the nonprofit world
cons: -can be a bit disorganized, since everyone tends to have a lot on their plate and turnover is a bit high

pros: Committed to the cause; High Integrity with donor fund; Gives freedom; Forward-looking and a fusion of Development and Business
cons: For execution team, places of work are not very conducive for family.

pros: Friendly and collaborative atmosphere, flexible working hours and meaningful work with real impact to communities.
cons:
Field based assignments mean you work close to the clients or farmers in remote areas which can be challenging if you have a family.
Shorter project funded by donors means that you don't see the full impact of some pro

review_title: A wonderful way to give back!
pros:
Brillant people making a difference
A real opportunity to change lives in a developing country at a young age (meaningful careers in non-profits can take years to get) 
A wonderful resume builder
cons: The typical challenge of working in a developing country...things move slow and it can be hard to motivate people to move quickly

review_title: Great Organization to get multidisciplinary sector experience
pros: Great work culture and top management (think tank)
cons: Frequent transfers/shift from one to another project (although good for learning new things)

pros: Extremely dedicated, skilled and knowledgeable staff, both in the field and at headquarters.   Pragmatic, grounded approach to solving poverty.  With the right champions and support, entrepreneurial culture enables you to carve your own path.
cons: Limited opportunities to progress within the organization, internal processes vary from highly structured (veering on bureaucratic) to undefined.

pros: Collaborative, good communicator, effective time management, effective decision maker, innovative and creative, problem solver and good planner
cons: Few challenges , delays on project execution due to funding,  Compliance to heath support average

job_title: Country Director in Abuja, Federal Capital Territory
pros: Very professional.  Efficient.  Transparent.  Honest.  Clear about who and what they want and what they expect in terms of performance and how you will be supported in your new role.
cons: Nothing visible.  Industry reputation is also very strong.  Well-respected company.

review_title: Best Place to work for international development
pros:
1. Highly talented and committed team
2. Diversified experience starting from development sector to strategic consulting
3. Very structured career path and Due recognition to employees's efforts
cons: Scope for strengthening capacity of support team at HQ (India)

pros: You get to learn and practice more on the job, hence gaining more experience at what you do best. Staff health is taken care of, with some other fringe benefits
cons: There's so much fieldwork involved, which if not planned properly, may affect life with family

pros: Heart is in the right place, and they do have positive impact on farmers' livelihoods.
cons: There is an obsession with hiring ex-bankers and ex-consultants who don't have much on-the-ground experience with what makes development work. While bright, these ex-professionals often propose theoretical solutions that aren't practical.

pros: Good paymaster,  fair and transparent performance appraisal system, offers friendly working environment and freedom of expresion
cons: frequent change in working locations, responsibilities overlapping across hierarchies and job insecurity at lower level

review_title: Great working environment for sharp economic impact driven individuals
pros: Integrity, impact driven, cost conscious, economically sound  programs, focus on high quality service delivery, calculate their impact Return on Investment for all projects, great Volunteer Consulting program, offer learning and growth opportunities
cons: Hardworking culture, varying quality of program implementation

pros: -Interesting project with a lot of responsibility
cons:
-Lack of support from TechnoServe employees to perform my tasks and to overcome risky / unsafe situations in a developing country
-Bad working environment

pros: Salaries are good if you reach higher level, but at lower level, not so much
cons:
Pretty much everything. The working environment. No flexibility. Micromanagement, dictatorial style of leadership, relationship management (funders and partners) is downright shabby. Too few people hold decision making, not just strategic but also operational.
No flexibility for timing. Fixed entry time, while exit time would depend on your commitments. Doesnt work like consulting firm.

review_title: Great vision & mission , can improve implementation and growth opportunities
job_title: M&E Officer in Maputo, Maputo Province
pros: It is a great organization to work. Various projects with opportunities to learn different things everyday
cons: The management is not very communicative, no opportunity to grow inside the organization

pros: They have great benefits and value a work/life balance.
cons: Do not promote within. Depending on the department, management does not value professional growth.

pros: Strong dedication to mission, excellent talent and thought leadership, a leader in its field
cons: Large organization and admin / finance systems lagging a bit, always too much going on

pros: A cool place to work with lot of new learnings, ease of access to leadership, Independent work culture, Onus of responsibility and opportunity to develop are the plus in the organisation
cons: e-communications for employee engagement will improve team spirit

pros:
Best learning platform
Freedom to explore and contribute 
Supportive team 
Time-bound assignments
cons: Sometimes senior team expects more than what needs to be done

pros:
Work for a noble cause
International development experience is unique
Opportunity to meet a lot of awesome, smart people (colleagues and expats)
cons: Don't have high expectations; the experience is what you make of it.

pros: The office is in a great area. The staff are so friendly and open to conversation and interns needing help/advice. Collegial atmosphere.
cons: The tasks range from engaging to deeply banal. Very slow-paced working expectation.

pros: As a fellow, you are paid per diem per day (rate varies according to where you are based). Projects are quite interesting.
cons: They can treat you like a PA, and give you menial tasks other people don't want to do.

review_title: Great impact, little disorganised within office
pros: Being part of a global organisation brings insights into great projects across the world.
cons: Levels of internal organisation and project management in country offices vary greatly and can be frustrating at times.

pros: Team was good and the job involves lots of travel. Good if you like it
cons: Given small team size, there was limited promotion / learning opportunities

pros: Excellent work in Agriculture livelihood projects.
cons: No dedication towards work in Mumbai project manager.Managers dont have relevant experience and not open for suggestions by experience people from concern field. Project suffers due to poor management & lack of supervision, lack of delegation of responsibilities and lack of effective utilization of skills of employee by manager and higher authority.

pros: good benefits, interesting salary increase during performance review, loads of experience and skills to acquire
cons: loads of turnover, focus on money from donors and not from projects impact on beneficiairies

pros: Nice place to work the staff are very resource and usually as a team.
cons: Nothing much say about, its just a very nice place to be.

pros: Smart people, great values and mission, amazing place to work
cons: More opportunities for professional development which is in the process of being addressed

pros: Modern organization, update with apps, web integrated,
cons: Although organization has good tools in place, implementation is the same in every country

review_title: Good to work here benefit for field worker

pros: High dedicated staffs are there
cons: As far as know I didn't observe the downside of working at TNS
